div.font: Remote Learning Days will be counted as student attendance days. It is important for a parent/guardian or student to sign-in every morning by 10:00am by filling out the appropriate Google Form. (please see below)
div.span: Thank you for your help with keeping our attendance accurate.

font.i: Dear Emmons' Families,
As always, I hope this email finds you and your family healthy and well.
Here is our schedule for the next two weeks:
Week of April 27th, Monday-Friday remote learning
Week of May 4th, Monday- teacher planning day, Tuesday-Friday remote learning

As we continue into the next month with remote learning, we hope you find the advice from an article from "Stomp Out Bullying" to be meaningful and timely. Take care of yourself, while you are taking care of your family. We are thinking of you!

"None of this is normal - not for any student. Without the predictable routine of school, sports, dance, clubs, music and in-person time with friends, our kids are feeling disconnected and an enormous loss. Their familiar way of life was gone in an instant. Kids and teens are grieving right now. Our advice? Honor that grief process.
DO NOT EXPECT: Youths to fall into a new routine without missing a step, to accept current times as normal, to move their entire lives indoors and online cheerily and capably.

DO EXPECT: Youths of all ages to act out, not want to get out of bed, not have words to express their inner turmoil, to have mood swings.We are guessing, after all, that you can relate. Parents are also grieving and experiencing loss. Insecurity and instability abound. All of Society is suddenly operating under unprecedented conditions. Many are losing jobs, are afraid to go out for basic necessities, are worried about loved ones near and far. Our advice: Be easy on yourself, too.

DO NOT EXPECT: That you will be a perfect “Homeschool” parent, that you will be cheery and productive at all times, that your family will emerge having not only completed assignments but also having learned a new language, peacefully completed a family project or become a master coder.

DO EXPECT: That it will be hard. Some days will be rocky for everyone. Emotions may take a roller coaster ride based on the news of the day or on the fact that there are ants on the counter. Expect anything.

Crisis Schooling is just one small piece of Crisis Living - which we are all enduring. When it comes to that schoolwork, get it done and then have fun - or better yet, find the most enjoyable ways to help your child learn. Read, listen to stories, bake, garden, play games…hands-on learning and time together can not only build the mind but the mental state too. And if it is one of those days where that seems too hard… perhaps your best today will be to cuddle up with your kids and just be together."

We are joining the COVID-19 Public Health Campaign in partnership with the Lake County Health Department. The campaign was formed to help localize efforts in responding to COVID-19. This week, we are sharing two videos from the campaign:
How to Protect Yourself from COVID-19
How to Protect Others from COVID-19
If you would like to participate in the free lunch program, please email Lisa Lawler at llawler@emmons33.org.
For technology issues, please email Mike Tonelli at tech@emmons33.org.

li.i: If you are finding it difficult to navigate Google Classroom and review your students' assignments, please follow these steps:
Have your student log into Google Classroom and click on one of the classes listed.
Click on the second tab at the top titled "Classwork". This page should give you a running list or weekly summary of all the assignments for that particular class.
If the icon by each assignment is gray, then your student turned in the assignment. If the icon is blue then your student has not turned in the assignment.
Repeat steps 1-3 for each of the classes listed in Google Classroom.

font.i: Finally, if you did not get a chance to fill out the family survey from last week, the survey will remain open through Monday. Here is the link: https://forms.gle/c9kTQWynK9RiHps8A
Dear Emmons Families,

i.font: Today, Governor Pritzker announced that all schools in Illinois will be closed through the end of the school year. Although we may have wondered if that might happen, it is still difficult to hear.

font.i: Families, we imagine that you will have many questions, which may include:

i.font: - Will there be Summer School for students with special needs?

font.i: - What will happen for 8th graders, who cannot now walk through graduation ceremonies in May?
- Will schools reopen in August?
As well, you may be thinking about student belongings which were left behind in desks, lockers, etc.

We are thinking about all of these concerns, and will provide information as we can. In the meantime, I know that you will continue doing what you can to keep your families safe, and your children learning.

i.font: Next week, we will have a remote learning planning day on Monday. Therefore, remote learning for your students will occur Tuesday, April 21st -Friday, April 24th. Monday is a wonderful day for your students to catch up on assignments and engage in specials (art, music, STEM, & library) enrichment opportunities.

font.i: I also wanted to check in with families this week. Please follow the link to the survey: https://forms.gle/u9v1qtegtniwAGkJ8. The survey will close on Monday, April 27th.
As always, please reach out if we can assist you. We continue to offer free lunches for any student in need (llawler@emmons33.org) and technology support (tech@emmons33.org). We are here for you.
